makers.displaymaker: Max Ernst, 1891–1976; born Brühl, Germany; died Paris, France; active Cologne, Germany, and Paris

texts.textentryhtml: Sylvia Slifka, bequest; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2004.
texts.remarks: as per bequest acceptance letter in curatorial file, AP

texts.textentryhtml: Shortly before he moved to Sedona, Arizona, in 1946, Ernst began collecting Hopi kachinas, carved dolls that represent spiritual messengers. Fascinated by the geometric shapes of their bodies, he drew connections between the dolls and the distortion and abstraction of bodily forms, elements seen in his earlier Surrealist practice. In Un ami empressé, Ernst created a double figure: what at first appears to be a tail becomes a second creature when the sculpture is observed from a different angle.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2004," Record of the Princeton University Art Museum 64 (2005): p. 91-135.
